description:
Fimicolochytrium jonesii is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Chytridiomycota. It is a saprobic organism, meaning it derives its nutrients from decaying organic matter. Fimicolochytrium jonesii is primarily found in soil and is known to colonize dung or other fecal matter. 

The fungus reproduces asexually through the formation of sporangia, which are structures that produce and release zoospores - small, motile spores capable of dispersal in aqueous environments. Fimicolochytrium jonesii is a chytrid, a group of fungi characterized by the presence of a single, posteriorly-directed flagellum on their zoospores, which aids in their movement and colonization of new substrates.

Taxonomically, Fimicolochytrium jonesii was first described and named in recognition of the contributions made by mycologist Dr. David Jones to the study of chytrid fungi. The species is classified within the order Chytridiales and the family Chytridiaceae based on its morphological and molecular characteristics.
